dublinCore.dc:title: 118 HR 1652 IH: Access to White House Visitor Logs Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Quigley introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Accountability

form.official-title: To require the disclosure of certain visitor access records.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Access to White House Visitor Logs Act.

section.header: Improving access to influential visitor access records

subparagraph.text: the residence of the Vice President; and
any other location at which the President or the Vice President regularly conducts official business.

paragraph.text: The term covered records means information relating to a visit at a covered location, which shall include—

subparagraph.text: the name of each visitor at the covered location;
the name of each individual with whom each visitor described in subparagraph (A) met at the covered location; and

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (c), not later than 30 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the President shall establish and update, every 90 days, a publicly available database that contains covered records for the preceding 30-day period.

paragraph.text: The President shall not include in the database established under subsection (b) any covered record—

subparagraph.text: the posting of which would implicate personal privacy or law enforcement concerns or threaten national security; or
relating to a purely personal guest at a covered location.

paragraph.text: With respect to a particularly sensitive meeting at a covered location, the President shall—

subparagraph.text: include the number of visitors at the covered location in the database established under subsection (b); and
post the applicable covered records in the database established under subsection (b) when the President determines that release of the covered records is no longer sensitive.
